Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples.

name: Nat.dvd_right_iff_eq
docString: Two natural numbers are equal if and only if they have the same multiples.

Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

name: Nat.even_or_odd
docString: Every natural number can be expressed as an even number (the sum of two identical numbers) or an odd number (2 times an integer plus 1).

This theorem states that the number 1 is not even. In the context of the definitions provided, an even number is defined as a number `a` that can be expressed as `a = r + r`, for some `r`. The theorem asserts that no such `r` exists for `a = 1`, i.e., 1 cannot be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers.

name: Mathlib.Data.Nat.Parity._auxLemma.10
docString: This theorem states that the number 1 is not even. In the context of the definitions provided, an even number is defined as a number `a` that can be expressed as `a = r + r`, for some `r`. The theorem asserts that no such `r` exists for `a = 1`, i.e., 1 cannot be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers.

Ordinal games are numeric.

name: SetTheory.PGame.numeric_toPGame
docString: Ordinal games are numeric.

The sum of two natural numbers is even if and only if both numbers are even or both are odd.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m + n) ↔ (Even m ↔ Even n)
name: Nat.even_add
docString: The sum of two natural numbers is even if and only if both numbers are even or both are odd.

This theorem, `Mathlib.Data.Int.Parity._auxLemma.19`, states that the integer 1 is not even. In the context of this theorem, a number is defined as even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers. However, there is no integer that, when doubled, equals 1, hence 1 is not considered even under this definition.

type: ∀ {α : Sort u_1} {a b : α}, (a = b) = (b = a)
name: Mathlib.Data.Int.Parity._auxLemma.19
docString: This theorem, `Mathlib.Data.Int.Parity._auxLemma.19`, states that the integer 1 is not even. In the context of this theorem, a number is defined as even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers. However, there is no integer that, when doubled, equals 1, hence 1 is not considered even under this definition.

A sum of finite numbers is still finite

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {s : Finset α} {f : α → ENNReal}, (∀ a ∈ s, f a ≠ ⊤) → (Finset.sum s fun a => f a) < ⊤
name: ENNReal.sum_lt_top
docString: A sum of finite numbers is still finite

docString: Nonnegative real numbers.

The convolution of two even functions is also even.

type:
∀ {𝕜 : Type u𝕜} {G : Type uG} {E : Type uE} {E' : Type uE'} {F : Type uF} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E'] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F] {f : G → E} {g : G → E'} {x : G}
  [inst_3 : NontriviallyNormedField 𝕜] [inst_4 : NormedSpace 𝕜 E] [inst_5 : NormedSpace 𝕜 E'] [inst_6 : NormedSpace 𝕜 F]
  (L : E →L[𝕜] E' →L[𝕜] F) [inst_7 : MeasurableSpace G] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure G} [inst_8 : NormedSpace ℝ F]
  [inst_9 : AddCommGroup G] [inst_10 : MeasureTheory.Measure.IsAddLeftInvariant μ]
  [inst_11 : MeasureTheory.Measure.IsNegInvariant μ] [inst_12 : MeasurableNeg G] [inst_13 : MeasurableAdd G],
  (∀ᵐ (x : G) ∂μ, f (-x) = f x) → (∀ᵐ (x : G) ∂μ, g (-x) = g x) → convolution f g L (-x) = convolution f g L x
name: convolution_neg_of_neg_eq
docString: The convolution of two even functions is also even.

type:

  (Finset.sum s fun i => f i) = ⊤ ↔ ∃ i ∈ s, f i = ⊤

docString: A sum of numbers is infinite iff one of them is infinite

The tails are equal

type:
∀ {F : PFunctor.{u}} {R : PFunctor.M F → PFunctor.M F → Prop},
  PFunctor.M.IsBisimulation R →
    ∀ {a : F.A} {f f' : PFunctor.B F a → PFunctor.M F},
      R (PFunctor.M.mk { fst := a, snd := f }) (PFunctor.M.mk { fst := a, snd := f' }) →
        ∀ (i : PFunctor.B F a), R (f i) (f' i)
name: PFunctor.M.IsBisimulation.tail
docString: The tails are equal

The set of natural numbers that are sums of two squares is closed under multiplication.

type: ∀ {a b x y u v : ℕ}, a = x ^ 2 + y ^ 2 → b = u ^ 2 + v ^ 2 → ∃ r s, a * b = r ^ 2 + s ^ 2
name: Nat.sq_add_sq_mul
docString: The set of natural numbers that are sums of two squares is closed under multiplication.
